children.subject: I think as of recently, you either need an A+ in 189 or an A in 194-26 to take 280. But my info might also be outdated

history.content:
194-26 isn't really computer vision, it's computational photography (a flavor of image processing). The class does do some CV stuff at the end, but it's not the focus.

If 194-26 isn't offered, a good alternative is either 123, which goes over methods similar to 194-26 (it's also a project-based image compression/manipulation/reconstruction class). This is assuming you have the 120 prereq, which is useful for image processing in its own right since 120 covers the theory of filtering and sampling.

I would consider 123 because 280 is notoriously difficult to get into as an undergrad.

====================================================

I have to respectfully disagree slightly with the above answer. Much of what was covered in CS194-26 is computer vision (especially classical computer vision) and is related to it. In recent years, they've even added a project related to modern computer vision techniques.

I took CS194-26 in Spring 2020 https://inst.eecs.berkeley.edu/~cs194-26/sp20/ when it was rebranded to be an undergraduate introduction to computer vision by Professor Efros. From the first lecture, "Course objectives: You will get a foundation in image processing and computer vision", and signups for CS280 this semester only allowed undergrads/masters students who had taken 194-26 and 189 and got A or higher to enroll.

Taking CS280 this semester, and a lot of it (so far) is review from CS194-26.

EECS 225B is a better class imo if you want to do computer vision like stuff than EE123 (digital image processing vs digital signal processing)

====================================================

OP here. DIP is two-dimensional DSP. The theory is the exact same (the Nyquist theorem is the Nyquist theorem no matter how many dimensions your signal is), though DIP does have some tricks specifically for human vision. But as an undergrad, it's good to get a solid understanding of DSP and its cool range of applications before tackling what is essentially a 2D DSP research class. Especially since EE 123 is project-based (the final project in 123 is an image processing project too).

There are some differences between how 225B and 123 are structured. 123 is much more similar to 194-26 since it's a guided undergraduate class that has fleshed-out class projects that form a neat portfolio for an undergrad. 225B is much more research-focused, with a big research project due at the end instead of structured course projects specifically designed to complement the course material.

I think for what most people take 194-26 for (a guided introduction to signal filtering and manipulation with cool and resume-worthy prepackaged course projects), 123 is a much more similar class. But if this isn't OP's specific use case, 225B is definitely also a good class in its own right.

194-26 isn't really computer vision, it's computational photography (a flavor of image processing). The class does do some CV stuff at the end, but it's not the focus.

If 194-26 isn't offered, a good alternative is either 123, which goes over methods similar to 194-26 (it's also a project-based image compression/manipulation/reconstruction class). I would consider 123 because 280 is notoriously difficult to get into as an undergrad.

children.subject: I hope 194-26 is offered, it looks like such a cool class.

history.content: Will CS 194-26 (computer vision) be offered next year? If not, what are the major differences between CS 194-26 and CS 280? Are undergrads able to enroll in CS 280?
history.subject: CS 194-26
